comment: You can clearly see how much respect Jimmy has for David. I mean, he had so many great artists at his desk but I have neven seen him like this. Like a little boy who meets his big idol.
replies:
['Yea! I had that feeling heâ€™s so used to lie appreciating the artist as the interviewer but today he was feeling the real emotion interviewing David and a sane bit of embarrassment for his modesty. It was like breathing fresh air from the past times, like when your grandma cooks and anyone else can do it as her â¤', 'Oh absolutely he looked like a kid in a toy shop, it was really endearing. (:', "Yeah, me too. I mean, Jimmy fakes his enthusiasm very well (like any other ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ host), but in this case it seems David's visit really meant a lot for him. Nice!", 'He met with Roger a few years back and bothered Waters to the point that he felt necessary to share with the crowd that the story of Syd wasn't a funny matter.

David hits the stage and all of a sudden, "Oh my gosh.....Syd Barrett...I'm such a fan."

Fallon is a paid crowd pleaser. He's pathetic.']

Great to see that a David Gilmour guitar solo can still make the hair on the back of my neck stand up in the same way as when I heard "Shine on you Crazy Diamond" on vinyl as a pre-teen in 1978. Love his work ğŸ‘
replies:
['I was born in 1978. I found a vinyl copy of The Wall at a flea market in 1990 and was instantly hooked.

Pre-internet of course I remember hearing rumours that a song called Shine On You Crazy Diamond existed. I found it at another flea market on concert bootleg after about a year of wondering.

Discovering music was so exciting back then!!']
